title: R45724
content: The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress was established by the House of Representatives on January 4, 2019, to examine and improve its internal procedures and operations. This committee follows previous efforts dating back to the 1940s aimed at strengthening Congress's role in the lawmaking process. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress, established by the House of Representatives, aims to investigate and develop recommendations for modernizing Congress. The committee's authorization ends on February 1, 2020, and includes twelve appointed Members with specific criteria for membership. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress differs from other committees in three key ways: party ratios are equal, service does not count towards membership limitations, and members are appointed by the Speaker based on recommendations from the minority leader. Speaker Pelosi selected Representative Derek Kilmer (WA) as chair on January 4, 2019. Derek Kilmer (WA) appointed chair of the Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress, with additional Democratic and Republican members named. The committee operates under specific procedures outlined in its authorizing resolution, with no legislative jurisdiction delegated to it. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress has a broad responsibility to study House operations and modernize its business. It is charged with investigating seven areas including rules, procedures, policies, staff recruitment, administrative efficiencies, technology, and the work of the Franking Commission. The committee established additional rules of procedure at its first meeting on March 12, 2019. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress, established on March 12, 2019, set its regular meeting day, quorum requirements, and questioning procedures for witnesses. A quorum is needed for hearings and markups, with early-bird rules for on-time arrival. The chair and vice chair have five minutes for opening statements, with a 10-minute limit overall. Questioning follows the five-minute rule, and any member can submit questions to the chair. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress, established on March 12, 2019, has set its regular meeting day, quorum requirements, and questioning procedures for witnesses. The committee operates under the five-minute rule for questioning, and members can submit written questions to witnesses within 10 business days of a hearing. The committee does not have the authority to issue subpoenas but can recommend them to the relevant standing committee. H.Res. 245 was passed to fund House committees during the 116th Congress, allocating $487,500 for the select committee's expenditures. Most of this amount is reserved for the first session of the Congress, with operations scheduled to end on February 1, 2020. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress, established in 2019, received interim funding and can utilize House staff services. The committee's first hearing focused on reform ideas from 35 Members, including changes to rules, House schedule, resources, and policymaking responsibilities. Subsequent hearings featured testimony on various proposals from Capitol Hill practitioners, former Members, and scholars. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress, established in 2019, is considering various proposals from Capitol Hill practitioners, former Members, and scholars. The committee will submit a final report to the House, which will include findings and policy recommendations. A two-thirds majority of the committee is required to publish the final report, necessitating bipartisan support. The Select Committee on the Modernization of Congress will need support from at least 8 out of 12 members to publish the final report, meeting a two-thirds threshold. House rules mandate that committee proceedings and documents be made public within 24 hours of each meeting adjournment. Records produced during the investigation will be shared with relevant standing committees, and recommendations in the final report must be made public within 30 days of submission to the House. The CRS experts are available to answer inquiries from congressional clients on specified topics.
